Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts: I reside in rural America, specifically in a small town in Michigan. Here, you transition from farmland to small tourist towns. There are no big city malls, no Wal-Mart, Target, or even an Applebee's. Wherever you need to go, you have to drive. Yet, I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world, surrounded by water. My "city" is encircled by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan on one side and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go, you can find a beach to dip your toes in the water. My neighborhood embodies the concept of a small town. Houses aren't packed together. They aren't cookie-cutter homes all built the same. They are older homes, some are being updated and remodeled, others are more vintage. Most homes have basements. Full basements you can see from the street. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses in every imaginable color in the blocks surrounding my home. Most houses have yards. Yards with trampolines and playsets. Some people have gardens and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hardworking people who work for a living and are either raising families or have already done so. On any given day, you'll see kids running up and down the streets. You'll also see people walking dogs, cycling, and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors, and you can tell who belongs and who doesn't. You'll see someone grilling outside and wave, or someone walking their dog from a few blocks away and smile warmly. Lawns are kept in good condition. No one has leaves piled up from fall. Green grass is mowed and kept under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards, they are trimmed. It's not a stunning neighborhood that you drive into and think, wow, look at the nice homes, but one you enter and think, this would be a good place to raise a family. It's quiet, peaceful, and safe. While it may look average, it is exceptional because it represents what people want in the world: a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance is the county sheriff's department and jail. The health department is right next to it. The city recycling center is just down the road, and neighbors and city residents utilize the services they offer. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside, and hear the rumble of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream shop, and if you're really into it, you can make your way downtown from our neighborhood. My kids can ride their bikes to the park, which is only about 8 blocks away. It's a truly great place to live.

The general area I live in can be seen as a typical cookie-cutter suburb. In particular, my neighborhood is clearly influenced by a homeowner's association. When you enter, you'll see only well-maintained single-family homes, which we owe to the homeowner's association. The front yards are quite similar, with a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Occasionally, you'll spot small trees. Everyone has a two-car garage. As you drive through, you'll notice newly paved roads. Despite the many families living here, the streets are in great condition, free of potholes or anything like that. Most houses are single-story, but you might see a few two-story homes as well. We don't have the typical individual mailbox setup you'd expect for single-family homes. Instead, there are large clusters of mailboxes at the end of the street, similar to apartments. Everyone uses a key to access their specific mailbox, and there are two larger lockers for packages. Again, the HOA's focus on uniformity is evident here. My house is located at the far edge of the nearby city, making my neighborhood a blend of rural and suburban. Thus, we have plenty of land for various purposes. There are multiple community pools accessible to residents, well-maintained and gated. Additionally, there are various walking trails for walking dogs or enjoying an evening stroll alone. You don't need to visit a park to exercise; the neighborhood is large enough to run around and get plenty of exercise. Most residents are retired, creating a safe environment where everyone looks out for each other. We also have a small number of middle-aged and young professionals. The city itself is surprisingly large in population but retains a small-town atmosphere. We have most expected amenities, including a single mall that's not huge but functional. It takes me about 15 minutes to drive to significant places, but once there, I find many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high-end groceries with organic foods to bargain outlets with limited stock and minimal staff to keep costs down. Overall, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We enjoy amenities like pools and walking trails, and although we're not adjacent to shopping areas, you can easily drive to any major store you prefer.

The first time I heard about my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who had disappeared. It was somewhat unexpected. Almost every apartment in the area was renting for over a thousand dollars a month. I hadn't heard anything about that story, nor had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know some of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are costly, but we've learned to be economical over the years. You start to appreciate the dusty smell of flea market toys and clothes with mothballs. You notice smells much less as an adult. You might start smoking, or maybe you're just too used to things as they are. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines piled on a closed piano. It embeds itself in the leather and remains even after washing. Here, there are three thrift stores within walking distance. If you start from the far end, you can visit two charity shops, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is bustling, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you wouldn't hear it in the thrift stores. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a pleasant place to lose an afternoon. There are more and more of those every year. Cars and people flood the area. It's a growing city, they say. As the headquarters of one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it still shows signs of growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everyone and everything is focused on their own goals, and there's not much anyone asks of you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you be. It's not like the South, where being a bit concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep your shell up as long as you like, and the city will crash and recede like waves on the shore. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur singers upstairs, there's always something happening. In a way, we have less of an apartment full of strangers and more of a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn at funerals, and help each other when we can. In some ways, I'm fortunate to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me well. I try to make sure to clean up after myself and leave them food, and they do the same in return. I bring them their mail and they bring mine. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I enjoy theirs. I live in a vast, dehumanizing modernist sprawl, but it's people like my neighbors who make me feel like I didn't completely ruin my life.

I live in a small town in the Midwest, just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood on the east side of town can be described as the most economically disadvantaged area. Property values are low, with most houses rented or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is neither unattractive nor unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates are slightly higher than in other parts of town, but still generally low. In the past ten years, there have been a few violent crimes a few blocks from my home, including some shootings and at least one homicide. Our next-door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside a local bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime, except for the occasional item disappearing from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. Overall, the town where I live has been significantly affected by the "opioid epidemic" impacting many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive aspects. My son's elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite his special needs, he has not faced any bullying so far, thanks to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, which he loves. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town's population lives below the poverty line, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students so that no child ever goes hungry. No child or family is treated as "less than" due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the town center and on the west side, where all the shopping areas are located and most traffic passes through. The east side, where I live, tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are excellent, and there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family's needs. Our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.

My neighborhood is rich in culture. It's located on a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical significance. I live in a seven-story apartment building directly across from the old live theater, and a block down the hill is a cool little arcade bar that attracts people of different kinds on warm summer nights. Often, especially on weekends in June and July, you'll see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's quite large considering the part of town it's in. Surrounding the park is concrete, with tall stairs built into the wall. During the cold winter months, homeless people set up their tents in neat rows along the sidewalk and the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the heavy downpours in mid-winter often make it hard to stay warm. Setting up their tents close together, in the center of town rather than out in the wilderness, keeps them much warmer. They're also within walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city, though, isn’t the beauty of its historical character—the tall, proud buildings, the architecture scattered throughout the varying levels of hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop was once the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. Stories are still told, even three decades later, about federal officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean up the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, even to newcomers like me, about those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the tougher neighborhoods in the city, to keep it clean. They still care about what happens in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around Hilltop after dark. I truly believe this warning echoes the old days and carries the bitter taste of social conditioning. Maybe it's because I am just dark enough to not completely pass as a "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly trouble our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions stem from ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I travel, Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who are more likely to offer me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes longer so I could charge my phone when I had nowhere to escape from the rain. It's a place where I've sat, thinking myself invisible, huddled against concrete storefronts on the greyest, dreariest nights, only to have someone stop, look me in the eye, hand me $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.

I moved to this neighborhood just as I was about to start eighth grade. At first, making friends was challenging, but I became close to someone living two houses away and another person on my street. Though neither lives here now, the memories remain. Most people from when I first moved in are still around. My neighborhood is quite like a typical American suburb, with lots of two-story homes. On weekends or warm days, I hear kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet on most days. I've never had any problems with the locals. You're left to yourself unless you need help. I've ordered many packages online, and none have been taken from my porch. I trust my neighbors. There's a park just a minute or two away from my house, full of memories. I've played basketball, football, and baseball there with others from the neighborhood. One of my worst memories happened there too, when I got hit in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, I visit the park to spend time with my cousin's kids. They're much younger and love swings and slides. Just the thought of going to the park excites them. The park now makes me nostalgic for various reasons. The neighborhood is diverse, with all kinds of food nearby. Within a mile, you can find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, many people now use apps like GrubHub and DoorDash for delivery. The most popular spots are fast food places, common in any suburb. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here have everything you might need. Several dry cleaners are nearby. There's a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street, along with a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is well-known in the Midwest. Some stores are diverse, such as an Indian-owned shop for homemade or ready-made Indian food. Overall, I like my neighborhood. Reading and watching news about the horror stories others experience with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.

My neighborhood is close to the college I attend, and for that reason, I enjoy living there. It's mostly apartment buildings, but there are a few restaurants and bars that are fun to visit and not too expensive. One of the bars was recently renamed and is more expensive, but the quality of service and drinks there isn't the worst. Most people are nice. They are either college students or have lower incomes since the apartment rent isn't very high. There are many children nearby because an elementary school is within walking distance of my apartment. I don't know my neighbors, but I don't really want to. They smoke a lot of weed, so the management put an air freshener unit right outside their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It's almost insulting. The buildings around me usually look quite old but might have renovated interiors. Further down the street, there are brand new apartments, but I don't like them because I know the construction wasn't particularly well done. They're cheaply built, but the rent is high, which I think is a scam, but because they're near the campus, the management gets away with it. There's a really cheap restaurant about five minutes away from where I live that serves food only on paper plates, and most of what they make is microwaved. Across from that is a gas station, which I've heard isn't a great place to work. But thanks to some funding from the city, the road was redone last summer, so now there's a nice big sidewalk and lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and the area is a bit nicer. However, the apartment building I live in is surrounded by trees. They've cut a few down, so there are some stumps, but there are many more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd Street, but right behind is 43rd Street, and that one isn't as nice. The sidewalks there are really bad and crumbling, and most of the buildings look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that's probably to hide the appearance of the buildings. Most of the crime in my area has occurred in an apartment complex on that street, but I can't just blame them. There are apartments across from me that also have a lot of crime and a rather transient population. But I think I like where I live. I can afford it, and there are plenty of useful amenities nearby. I especially like that the university is within walking distance and there are two bus stops, so I can easily get to the store and downtown.

My neighborhood consists of duplexes on a cul-de-sac. They are spaced in such a way that they resemble individual houses. The only difference is that each is painted yellow with white porches and green metal roofs. Almost everyone is friends with each other, though not all. In the evenings, we gather at the end of a driveway that isn't predetermined and chat while the neighborhood's small children play with their toys, sidewalk chalk, or fly kites. It's a refreshing break in this modern, overly mechanical and computer-filled world. It's like stepping back in time. We are surrounded by fields and trees, complemented by blue skies and fluffy white clouds. The only downside? This season, we have tornado warnings, and for the first time last night, we heard the actual tornado sirens, so we had to head to shelter. You would find me in my bathtub, holding my smallest dog, along with my purse and a few pillows. My big dog wanted nothing to do with the bathroom and stayed in the living room, nervous and barking due to the strange circumstances. The neighborhood was quiet except for the sound of large hail falling to the ground. After the storm, the road was literally steaming due to the temperature change. We went from 92 to 75 degrees in just minutes. The hail melted immediately upon hitting the hot pavement. As I looked up at the clearing skies, the sun came out, and it started to rain. A double rainbow appeared. I ran into the house to get my camera and quickly took pictures to share with my friends and family on Facebook. They were amazed, as was I. The streets stayed quiet for another hour before some people finally came home from wherever they were when the storm hit. Then it was back to normal, with moms and children outside while dinner cooked. It's such a friendly neighborhood for someone like me who recently moved from NH to NC. I love the southern accent that people have. I have a two-bedroom, two-bath apartment, as does everyone. Although all the houses look the same on the outside, not all the apartments are the same inside. Some are actually quite small. It doesn’t make sense to me. I love to walk along the largest field behind where I live and wander down to the pond that isn't suitable for swimming. I've seen deer, and in the morning, you can hear the giant bullfrog singing. It's a fantastic place to live, just forty minutes outside the city of Charlotte. Each morning is greeted by the sound of roosters crowing from the nearby farms. It's like living in a small community village of its own. We even have a donkey at a nearby farm that you can hear braying in the evening to let us know he's there. I was fortunate to find this gem of a neighborhood.

Well, given that I've been here for about 10 years, I think I can share what I know. Initially, I was quite sad when I first arrived in my neighborhood. I moved from Riverdale to Stockbridge, and I won't lie, I cried because I missed them and loved them. But my mom and dad wanted the best for me and my little sister, so we relocated to a better place for housing, a better high school; everything was considered "not ghetto" when we moved to our new neighborhood. Over the years, I got used to it and made some new friends, as well as some new enemies at school. I never really got to know my neighbors over the years, except for Mr. Glen and his kids, along with Dennis for a while, both right next to us. They were pleasant people whom I can almost consider family in a way, and I truly appreciate them. I remember when my mom, dad, sister, and I went to Mr. Glen's wedding (they got remarried). It was really fun and enjoyable, to say the least, and something I'm looking forward to someday, as I build my wealth and give my future wife the life of a queen. When Mr. Glen's wife, Ms. Veda, took off the small white strap from her leg and tossed it, I caught it! Sadly, I didn't catch the flowers! We danced the night away, and I really enjoyed having a good time with Marsharii, one of their daughters. I haven't seen her since, though. I hope she has moved on to bigger and better things. The neighborhood itself is like a maze, although now I have a GPS, so I can take more time to explore it. I've only gone so far, and that was when I hung out with my friends Kason and Curtis. We all used to play video games a lot and just enjoyed life to the fullest as much as we could. Sometimes I would go to the park and enjoy nature, which soothes my soul. It gives me a sense of calmness and peace these days. I'll also bring some sticks I bought from the home depot and just practice my balance, and bring my bokken wooden sword if I can. I have fun enjoying what I love to do. There's also a basketball and tennis court, although I haven't played tennis or basketball in a long time, it's still nice to have in case I ever want to pick it back up and give it another go. My dad raised me and my best friend on tennis with Mr. Graves, and we always had a great time. They worked us hard! But we always had fun. I guess there are many times I've had fun in this neighborhood, and there are plenty of stories, but these are the ones that really stood out to me, and I believe that the best is yet to come!

My neighborhood is a charming small town. It doesn't stand out from others in South Carolina, but it has a significant impact on the agricultural sector. Johnston is known as the Peach Capital of the World, something the town proudly displays on the welcome sign. It is primarily made up of farmland dominated by either peach trees or cattle. Houses that aren't in the main part of town are spaced far apart; most are two stories with either metal roofs to combat the scorching summer heat or gray shingles. These houses are often not near the road but set further back, allowing the front fields to be used for animals or crops. In the main part of town, there is a single traffic light hanging at a crossroads. This is where the only stores in the entire town are located. There are three places to get "fast food": Hong Kong, a small Chinese restaurant run by a single family, Fiesta Mexican Restaurant, or Gary's, a small burger chain. There used to be a pizzeria, but it closed recently. There is a very small family-owned pharmacy called Maxwell and Halford Drug; amusingly, they are best known for the Cherry Coca-Cola they sell. There is a small but expensive grocery store called Independent Grocers Alliance, more commonly known as IGA. Although it is the only grocery store in the entire town, many people stop only to pick up one or two items; most prefer to travel to a Walmart in Batesburg-Leesville to purchase most of their groceries. The most popular store in the entire town is Dollar General; this store sells a wide variety of everyday items and is often busy from opening until closing time! There is a very small furniture store, Possibilities Furniture & More, run by a kind woman well-known in the community. The store has been in Johnston for many years and even employs two movers who deliver the purchased furniture! Attached to the furniture store is a small pet groomer called Clark's Cuts and Kennels. They offer a multitude of services such as daycare, boarding, grooming, nail grinding, bathing, etc. Both a doctor's practice and a veterinary practice are located away from the main part of town; they are both very small practices but well-equipped to assist the residents of Johnston. There is a single elementary school called Johnston Elementary School. Once students complete fifth grade, they must attend both middle and high school in the next town. Technically, there are no parks in the town, but they are currently in the process of creating a 2.5-acre recreational area to provide families with more opportunities for outings and attract more visitors or potential residents. Admittedly, there isn't much to do; there are no movie theaters, bowling alleys, "hang out" spots, playgrounds for children, areas to walk pets, or a large variety of restaurants. Despite this, it's a nice town, so small that you could pass through it in the blink of an eye without realizing it!

I reside in a typical suburban area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting road between two state highways, so we experience a bit more traffic on the street than I'd prefer, but aside from that, it's a quiet neighborhood. Not many people move in or out, so I've become familiar with most of the residents. People mostly keep busy with yard work and other daily chores. In winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. Our house is at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day and are familiar with the cars people drive around here. Whenever we spot an unfamiliar vehicle, we tend to notice it. Some neighbors take walks for exercise or to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes, which is just as you'd expect. We are home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us: myself, my wife, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We go outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Occasionally, we grill outside on our back deck, and there's always a pleasant barbecue aroma. It seems like someone is always mowing the lawn around here, and you can hear a lawnmower nearly every day from March until around October when the grass finally stops growing. We have many trees in our neighborhood, as it was originally a wooded area, so there's plenty of shade but also lots of leaves in the fall. This means raking and burning the leaves annually. I enjoy the smell of burning leaves too, so it's always a nice sign that fall has arrived. Recently, we haven't had much winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we rarely use the front door unless someone knocks, which is uncommon. I like working in the garage on my truck or other projects, and when the garage doors are open, I feel more connected to the neighborhood. On holidays, it's pretty quiet around here. At Thanksgiving, some neighborhood families host visitors from out of town, and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same on other holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I enjoy living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.

My neighborhood is situated right in the middle of the high desert, where there's dirt, dirt, and more dirt. Unless someone has actually lived here, they probably don't grasp the feeling of constantly seeing brown, and when you do spot a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on its care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spaced far apart. Now, it's quite similar, but there are many new additions. Honestly, this place looks more like a city every day, but I suppose most places are changing in the same way. Most people here are very friendly, but like any city, there are good and bad parts. In my neighborhood, I'm surrounded by friendly seniors; I guess it's a nicer area. The stores here are mainly chain stores like Food 4 Less and Smart & Final. If you want upscale options, you have to travel; I never really see any Whole Foods or similar stores. The most common jobs in my city, not officially recorded, are in construction. I think this is because the city is still not very developed, with many open spaces to build on. That somewhat worries me; I like things as they are now. I left a big city and don't wish to return. Speaking of construction, this is the field where my full-time job is; I am a drywall and T-bar installer. What I enjoy about my home is the variety of animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not least for the stark beauty of the desert itself. The high desert climate and terrain have created challenging ecosystems that need protection and support diverse wildlife. Human residents should take time to understand the non-human residents sharing this environment to coexist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted well to the wildlife. I have three children, all fascinated with lizards and desert bugs; as I write this, they are outside trying to catch different specimens. In terms of attractions, we have a few. Additionally, Victorville is a great place for families to experience the desert. It offers a different experience. If possible, plan your visit to coincide with the annual San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with a mix of activities and fun, the Victorville way. Visit nearby Wrightwood to see snow-covered mountains and try some winter sports to complete your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum features geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of Victorville's societal and industrial development.

When asked to describe my neighborhood, I believe my answer is somewhat unique. While others responding to this are likely homeowners with their own distinct lives, my situation is a bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus where I live, and the people in my dormitory to be my community. I also see the surrounding campus as part of my neighborhood, though to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some common features with more traditional ideas of a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the one I reside in has houses, people, stores, and parks. Let's start by discussing the "houses" that make up my neighborhood. Before exploring these houses, it would be best to clarify the types of housing available in my area. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity: the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. Firstly, in the apartments, there are usually 2-4 people in any given room, and about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can accommodate about 2 floors, so on average, there are around 20 people living in each building. Secondly, there are actual houses available for anyone affiliated with the school to rent. Typically, these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them. However, there are only a few of these houses scattered throughout the neighborhood, as they are less efficient. Finally, there are the typical dorm rooms that house hundreds of students. In these, two people share a room, with some exceptions, and this is the most common type of housing in my neighborhood. With housing covered, we can move on to the people. My school prides itself on diversity, which is reflected in the makeup of my neighborhood. There are people from all cultures and ages living here. Most of the professional staff reside in the houses located in the neighborhood, while the newer students stay in the dormitory-style housing, and the older students live in the apartment-style housing. The people in this neighborhood cannot be fully appreciated just by talking about them, so it is best to move on to the stores and parks in my neighborhood. Since my school functions as its own self-contained neighborhood, it has a variety of stores and a single park. The stores are a mix of dining options found in any other neighborhood, alongside the school's unique brand of clothing and grocery stores. Thus, anything needed can be found within the boundaries of my neighborhood! Additionally, the park in my neighborhood serves as a playground for all the diverse people here, and it is kept clean and free of crime by all the members of the neighborhood!

There are not many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downwards, and my house is right at the peak of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "workout hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily exercise. Since there are no sidewalks at all on my street, everyone walks on the road. The road is uneven in some places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electrical wires strung around the block look tattered. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often damage the power lines and the constant repairs make them look patchy and patchwork-like. There are many tall evergreen trees everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees block the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after another to take in the view of the bay. It's beautiful around sunset when the water seems to light up from below and the sky turns orange. However, it's more often cloudy, so you see most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked in my driveway for a month, and when I went to use it, it was green and furry with moss. It took me three hours to scrape it all off. There aren't many children where I live, although there's a school just a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting in people's yards or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open, you risk them sneaking into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it out the front door. Rabbits run wild in the area. Some of them are quite large, and gardeners hate them because they dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them, though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and occasionally a hawk or eagle flies by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any shops nearby, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront, there are a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There's not much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to throw into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shore clearly even through the mist on most days.

If you're planning to visit Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you won't have a hard time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular modes of travel in New York City. Bensonhurt is quite an urban neighborhood, so it will still feel like you're in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has seen an influx of Asian residents. Because of this, you'll find an Asian-owned store on almost every block as you walk. Supermarkets and laundromats are especially popular. Incidentally, these businesses are very popular with locals, as the quality of food in the supermarkets is excellent, prices are much cheaper, and they are very convenient. Near where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within a two-minute walking distance of each other. This further adds to the convenience of accessing groceries. I'm not saying Bensonhurst is solely inhabited by Asian residents, though. It's quite diverse, with immigrants and their first and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the area are Asian-owned. Besides these Asian-owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has about ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy in summer. Since we're in New York City, of course, the parks are very diverse. You'll see all kinds of diversity here, with people able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren't many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you'd find are for co-op living or condominium apartments. Most of the living spaces here are two-family houses, though. Most people are quite nice, but it can be very noisy. Every day, you'd hear cars blasting music as they drive by your house or constantly revving their engines, which will wake you up in the morning. If you plan on visiting at night, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You might run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies, and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past through physical assault, but that was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package theft. Although common, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, even though New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people here don't follow the rules. Every morning, you'll see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station or the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the ground everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!

The first thing you need to understand about Portland, Oregon is the meaning of "weird". The unofficial town motto, displayed on the back of a building that functions as a pizza place, bar, music venue, and strip club, while skirting legal limits on at least half of these activities, is "Keep Portland Weird". For some, this is a small plea to remember the Portland of the 90s and early 2000s, a Portland that was less well-known and less expensive, fostering creative and unique subcultures. For others, it is an invitation - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but this time as a compliment. Despite the influx of wealthy Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to accommodate them, Portland remains weird. Weird doesn't always mean accepting, but it does mean embracing things that are typically not accepted. Weird doesn't mean we lack modern conveniences and contemporary challenges. Like the rest of the nation, most of our goods are imported from China. There are countless ways to be weird, to be different, but Portland also has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps being weird means we just take all this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many areas of Portland, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers, herbs, and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summer. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard containers with things someone is giving away, but they can also be plastic bags or boxes. They often hold something magical, a treasure just right for the passerby, surprisingly often. Free boxes typically contain clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of strolling through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland means to me, but I am just one type of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never consider picking their clothes from a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with actual goats) or to Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all kinds of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug issues often stem from mental health problems, and the constant rain for much of the year, along with the gloomy clouds, seem to contribute. Portland also has a homelessness problem, which no one seems to know how to resolve. The homeless are drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than most places in the country, but like everywhere else, our services are inadequate. The non-homeless population oscillates between care and resentment. In this, we are not weird at all.

The mountains are always present. In the north, they witness the sun's journey each morning and evening. No matter how often I forget them or how busy I am with work and life, they remain, steadfast, unchallenged, and unfazed by life's challenges. On days when I am most stressed and tense, they demand to be noticed, and when I turn to them, they allow my restless soul to rest, giving me strength to continue, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my studies, and it was the mountains north of the campus that first captivated me. Of course, the university has its breathtaking views of buildings, ponds, and trees, which hold a place in my heart, but it's the mountains that truly hold the crown. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine-fueled studying. One can walk a little further or take the bus to the downtown area and be enveloped by an aura of antiquity from the faded colored bricks lining the restaurants and office buildings. Here, this seemingly suburban town shows as much hustle and energy as the neighboring big city. However, this doesn't last for many blocks, as one can retreat back to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such close proximity gives this city a truly wondrous vibe, as if it were waiting to be explored. This makes it easy to create many cherished memories, each linked to a particular part of the town. Whether it's walking past the rusty swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the bustling downtown to catch a movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Yet, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a fitting place for reflection or for crying sessions at two in the morning during an existential crisis. The latter is something I know well. While watching the turtles, ducks, and insects live their lives, each with a contribution or role, I couldn't help but ponder my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, past the park and small houses shouting suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that the sun cast its brilliant rays over the palm trees, painting the sky along its path, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. And sure enough, they were there, as they always had been. The sturdy, imposing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building on the horizon, and as if speaking without words, they stirred within me a sense of perseverance.

You might overlook it at first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not where one would expect living spaces. At least, not ones most people would choose to live in. But if you walk past the old, abandoned Whole Foods and go behind the hotels that are only occupied annually, apart from a few summer family reunions, you'll find a whole bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, there are a handful of apartment complexes - carefully placed next to each other like Russian nesting dolls meticulously taken apart and lined up piece by piece. The first apartments you come across are those known in the news for rather unsavory dealings, so we won't focus much on them - appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes next to them, are a whole other world unknown to almost anyone living in this area. Across from these complexes is a satellite campus of a community college - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel by the road, where students arrive with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to start their sleepy day. The iron gates creak open to let them in one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at the traffic delay when attendance is higher. The road merges into another residential street, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture and a lazily turning ceiling fan that stirs the warm, thick summer air. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park, doing cartwheels and somersaults over the prickly green blades, while bees lazily buzz around the flower patches by the road. Old retirees walk their dogs on the path, frowning at teenagers on skateboards and nodding politely at the teenage girls gathered around the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi restaurant in a strip mall beside the park that serves inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right next to it, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken - the beauty of a strip mall. There is also a frozen yogurt place there, of the DIY variety, and you often see the teens in the park with cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings, doing stunts on their skateboards and vaping because they think it's the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy South where hardly anything changes, not even time.

My neighborhood is fascinating. Most houses are for single families, but some have been divided into two while remaining attached, if that makes sense. My house has a small yard in front and a small driveway to the left. Like many others, it reminds you of a time not long ago when living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream once embraced the people of this country, but now it's slipping away. Yet my neighborhood and many others still stand, still calling out to us and visitors that the dream is still alive, and we are holding onto it as best as we can. People aren't as optimistic as they used to be, the upkeep of the small yards isn't what it once was, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, and young people still play as if the world around them was their whole existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems to conjure a future for today's youth while stirring nostalgia in older residents. Churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All the homes look different, but feel the same. There's a large supermarket called Super "A," owned by a large Yemeni family, likely the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The majority of residents are African American. The streets are wide, and the kids usually play football, only pausing to let cars pass. Most people in my neighborhood have been here for generations, and many can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when Hollywood stopped making Karate Kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the Karate Kid, so it's now a pharmacy because drugs supposedly make everything better, or so I've heard. There's also a small movie theater that shows old films at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdain for its lack of new releases, but favored by the elders who think it's a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids, of course. There's a single expressway passing through my town, though the exits and entrance are in the neighboring town. There was once a petition to get an exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders were against it. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, according to the elders, who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new high school, and we are trying to decide on a mascot for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would best represent my town.

Living in a large city, my neighborhood is incredibly diverse. Residential areas are seemingly randomly scattered among commercial zones where various businesses operate. Some of these businesses include offices, while others are different stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues. There’s no shortage of new restaurants to try or shops to explore. While some stores are large, well-known brands owned by big corporations, small boutiques are also becoming popular. They are not only found in various malls but also line the streets, often within walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and peaceful if not for the many attractions nearby. There are also a couple of parks nearby, and I’ve noticed that people often visit these parks with their young children. Speaking of people, there is quite a bit of diversity in my neighborhood. In one small area, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a group of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Extending a bit further outside my neighborhood, there are many more people of various races and origins, though they are sometimes clustered into their own small communities within the city. We have areas known as Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and many more, just a few miles away. However, even a short distance of a few miles can turn into a very long drive. A trip of just 10 miles can sometimes take two hours because of traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere. While certain places of interest are inevitably close by, the city is vast, and people generally do not prefer to travel on foot. Consequently, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and finding parking spots can be difficult almost anywhere. Ironically, there’s been a lot of construction in recent years as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are dismayed by the thought of even more people moving in and more vehicles on the roads. However, there are many different types of houses in my city. Not everyone lives or wants to live in a large apartment building. Residential areas consist of houses of various sizes, as well as smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties have single-family homes, while others have duplexes. This is true even within my immediate neighborhood, so there is no lack of diversity in housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood consists of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with most of my neighbors. It is not really a close-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor and a few other friends from the neighborhood who were all close to my age.

"Where is everything?" she asked as we drove past the cornfields stretching across the horizon. "This is it!" I replied, aware she would be stunned by the open landscape's sparseness. Coming from a town where the grocery store was just a five-minute walk from her house, she had never experienced so much open space in her life. Taken aback by the vastness of the cornfields, I shared with her what it was like growing up in rural Ohio, and at that moment, she finally understood who I was and where I came from. Traveling along a two-lane country road, you eventually arrive at a water-filled quarry. Just beyond it is the small community where I live. The houses are mostly made of brick and stucco. Each home has at least half an acre of land, which everyone takes pride in maintaining. In spring, the abundance of annual flowers complements the Midwestern trees that change with each season. The driveways are filled with top-of-the-line Mercedes-Benz luxury cars that gleam in the midday sun after a thorough car wash. As you continue down the road towards my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly demeanor. He often spends the entire day mowing his lawn, and you can hear him singing over the hum of his mower. Everyone in the neighborhood enjoys his presence; he is always genuine and an incredible person with a unique past. Though age has taken some of his sharpness, he was once a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deere Zero Turn mower. Eventually, you reach my house. In the side yard, geese are abundant and chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream feeding into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional "moo" from nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge lies an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. This was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to 'hunting' animals (which mostly meant chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child to befriend. The winters in my small town can be harsh yet incredibly beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into a barren wilderness. Trees that once held vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers become bare skeletons of bark. When blessed with occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is adorned with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I often fought as children, and during winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We built massive igloo-like forts to house our arsenal, usually made with branches. In our own little wonderland, we played make-believe during a time when nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
The first time I'd heard of my place, I was listening to a podcast about people who'd gone missing. It was a little surprising. Almost every apartment in the area was going for over a thousand dollars a month. I'd never heard anything about that story and neither had any of my friends. Maybe it's the struggle. I know a few of my friends cry themselves to sleep at night. Things are expensive, but we've learned how to be frugal over the years. You start to like the dusty smell of flea market toys and mothballed clothes. You smell a lot less in adulthood. You might start to smoke, or you might just be too accustomed to the state of things. But the flea market always asserts itself. The smell of adulthood is dusty magazines stacked on a closed piano. It wedges itself in the leather and stays in even after you wash it. Here, there're 3 thrift stores in walking distance. If you start on the far side, you can patronize two charity thrifts, a library, a rare book store, and a curio shop. Downtown is dense, cars and people fill the streets every morning, but you'd never hear it in the thrifts. No matter how many people or cars pass by, the store is silent. It's a nice place to lose an afternoon. Every year, there's more and more of those. Cars and people flood it. It's a developing city, they say. Headquartering one of the largest online empires for e-commerce and delivery, it's still showing growing pains. It reminds me of New York. Everything and everyone is set on their own goals, and there isn't a whole lot anyone asks from you. You can be alone, quiet, and independent, and people will leave you alone. It's not like the South, where being a little concerned means you care. You don't pry into anyone's life here, really. You can keep up your shell as long as you'd like, and the city will crash and roll back like waves on the beach. It's a lively place to be. Between the pianist next door and the two amateur vocalists upstairs, there's always something going on. In a way, we have less of an apartment of strangers and more a community of friends. We come together for our needs, celebrate birthdays, mourn funerals, and help each other when we can. In a way, I'm lucky to be here. I quite like most of my neighbors and they treat me pretty well. I try to make sure to clean after myself and leave them food and they do the same in kind. I bring mail to them and they to me. It's nice to see them and I believe they enjoy my presence as much as I do theirs. I live in a massive, dehumanizing modernist sprawl but it's people like my neighbors that make me feel like I didn't totally ruin my life.
I live in a small Midwestern town that is just outside the suburban areas of a major city. My immediate neighborhood, on the east side of the town, could be described as the most economically disadvantaged area of the town. Property values are low, with most houses being rented to or owned by low-income individuals. However, it is not unattractive or unpleasant. My neighbors are generally friendly people who will smile and say hello when I walk down the street. Crime rates, while slightly higher than other parts of town, are still generally low. There have been a few violent crimes in the past ten years within a few blocks of my home, including a few shootings and at least one homicide. Our next door neighbors lost their son in a shooting outside an area bar last year. Fortunately, our family has not been directly affected by crime other than having an occasional item disappear from our porch if we forget to bring it inside. In general, the town in which I live has been profoundly affected by the “opioid epidemic” that has affected many parts of the United States. Many lives have been lost due to fentanyl overdoses. Fortunately, there are many resources in my town to combat this epidemic, including several addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training sessions for families and friends of those affected by addiction. Despite these challenges, this town has many positive attributes. My son’s elementary school has excellent staff, from the principal to the teachers and support staff. Despite having special needs, he has not faced any bullying thus far due to the incredibly positive atmosphere of the school, and he loves it there. We have an active PTO that plans multiple events throughout the year to promote family involvement and educational progress. Because over 20% of our town’s population lives below the poverty level, the elementary school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students, so that no child ever has to go hungry. No child or family is treated as “less than” due to an inability to pay, and costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips are very reasonable. The City Council and staff have made many improvements to the appearance of our town, including repaving roads, landscaping, and refurbishing city parks. Unfortunately, most of these improvements have taken place in the center of town and on the west side, where all of the shopping areas are located and most of the traffic passes through. The east side where I live tends to be neglected, which is a point of contention for those in my neighborhood. Overall, I do enjoy living in this town. People are generally friendly, the schools are great, there are enough shopping options (both small businesses and larger retail stores) to meet my family’s needs, and our home may not be worth much, but it is comfortable and adequate. Our family has lived here for over 16 years, and we cannot imagine living anywhere else.
My neighborhood is full of culture. It's set upon a hill, surrounded by buildings with historical meaning. I live in a 7 story apartment building right across from the old live Theater, and a block down The Hill, is this cool little arcade bar that different types of people flock to on warm summer nights. Often times, especially on the weekends in June and July, you will see a line of people waiting to get in. A few blocks up is the nearest city park. It's pretty big considering the part of town it sits in. Encircling the park is concrete, with tall stairs poured into the wall. During the frigid winter months, homeless people set their tents up in neat little rows along the sidewalk and along the wide steps. It doesn't snow much, but it rains, and the torrential down pour in the mid-winter months often tends to make it difficult to keep warm. Setting their tents up close together, in the center of town rather than out in the jungle, keeps them much warmer. They're also within reasonable walking and transit distance to the only family center for miles, where they can bathe and shower. What I love about my city though, isn't the beauty of the historic nature- the tall proud buildings, the architecture that is spattered through-out the varying levels of the hills that roll down towards the ocean. What I love about my neighborhood is the culture of the people themselves. You see, Hilltop once was the most notorious neighborhood on the West Coast for gang violence. You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I moved to this neighborhood just when I was about to start eighth grade. It was hard for me to make friends at first, but I ended up getting close to someone who lives two houses down from me and another guy that lives on my street. Neither of them lives there anymore but the memories are still there. The same people who lived here when I first moved here are still here for the most part. My neighborhood is pretty similar to your average American suburban neighborhood. The neighborhood has a lot of two-story houses in it. Every weekend or just whenever it is warm outside I hear the kids playing outside. The neighborhood is quiet most days of the week. I have never had a problem with any of the people in the neighborhood. You are left alone in this neighborhood unless you need help. I have ordered multiple packages online and have never gotten a package snatched off of my porch. I feel like I can trust my neighbors. There is a park a minute or two away from my house. I have a lot of memories there. I have played basketball, football, and baseball there with the other guys in the neighborhood before. I also ended up with one of my worst memories there when I got elbowed in the nose playing football, but the good memories outweigh the bad. Nowadays, whenever I go to that park it is to spend time with my cousin's kids. They are much younger than me and still like playing on swings and slides and all of that type of stuff. Just the thought of going to the park makes them excited. The park makes me very nostalgic for a number of different reasons now. The neighborhood is very diverse. You will find all kinds of food nearby. In just a one mile radius, you would be able to find Chinese, Indian, Mexican, and Italian restaurants. However, nowadays, a lot of people just use apps just as GrubHub and DoorDash to get their food delivered to them. The most popular food places are the fast food shops but you can get those near pretty much any suburban neighborhood. There are also plenty of pizza places. The stores here contain everything you would ever need. There are multiple dry cleaners nearby. There is a Walgreens and a CVS on the same street as well as a Jewel-Osco grocery store, which is popular in the Midwest. Some of the stores are even diverse as there is an Indian-owned store if you are ever in the mood to make some homemade Indian food or to buy some ready-made Indian food. Overall, I am a fan of my neighborhood. Reading on social media and seeing on the news some of the horror stories other people have to go through with their neighbors makes me grateful for mine.
My neighborhood is nearby to the college that I attend, and for that I quite enjoy living there. There are mostly apartment buildings, but a few restaurants and bars that are fun to go to and aren't terribly expensive to go to. One of the bars was just renamed, and that one is more expensive to go to but it isn't really the worst quality of service or drinks there. Most of the people are nice. They are either college kids or they are lower income, since the apartment housing isn't very expensive. There's a lot of children nearby since there is an elementary school within walking distance of my apartment. I don’t know my neighbors, but I don’t really want to. They smoke a lot of weed and so the management of my building put an air freshener unit right across from their door, which my boyfriend and I found very funny. It’s almost insulting. The buildings that are around me are usually pretty old looking but might have renovated interiors. Down the street a bit there are brand new apartments, but I don’t like them because I know the construction done on them wasn’t particularly good. They’re cheaply built but the rent is expensive, which I think is such a scam but because they’re near campus, the management of those buildings can get away with it. There is a really cheap restaurant about five minutes from where I live that serves food only on paper plates and most of what they make is microwaved. Then across from that is a gas station, which I’ve heard isn’t a very good place to work. But thanks to some money from the city, the road was redone last summer so that there’s a nice big sidewalk, lots of grass on the medians and sides of the roads, and now the area is a little nicer. But the apartment building I live in is shrouded in tress. They cut a few of them down, so there are a few stumps, but there are a lot more trees where I live than down the road. Behind my apartment complex is a tree line and then another set of apartments. I live on 42nd street, but right behind is 43rd street and that one isn’t as nice. The sidewalks are really bad and falling apart, and most of the buildings on it look shabby. There are a lot of trees on this street, but that is probably to hide what the buildings look like.
